choices.C: Develop a VM image on an on-premises hypervisor and upload it to the cloud via API.
choices.A: Develop a VM image on an on-premises hypervisor and send it on a physical hard drive to the cloud provider's datacenter.
choices.D: Host the server on premises and integrate it with the IaaS service using the hybrid cloud model.
choices.B: Use a bare metal service instead of IaaS and verify that the bring-your-own OS feature is available.

discussion.content: D best

B. 

Bare Metal Cloud allows customers to control the hypervisor or operating system installed directly on the hardware.

https://www.lightedge.com/blog/what-is-bare-metal-cloud/
The answer is B. It cannot be D because the OS isn't offered by the CSP, so what would you want from the cloud with a hybrid model??

questions.question_text:
A cloud architect is deploying a VM in a public IaaS cloud. The software that will be installed on the VM is not compatible with any of the OS versions in the system images offered by the IaaS vendor.
Which of the following is the BEST way to deploy a VM with the required OS?

questions.answer_description:
Part 1:
Router 2 is the problem and this should be selected. If you examine the preshared key used for the VPN you will see that it is not configured with the correct key.
It is using Cloud002 while router1 is using Cloud001
Part 2:
Update the PSK (Pre-shared key in Router2)
Add the Application Server at on-premises to the Load Balancer

discussion.content: I have seen so many different answers for this question. What's the actual answers with explanations
correct answer is A, H

this is kind of funny...

it says a cloud engineer deployed an email server in a "public cloud". assuming this is a vendor providing the service, then the FIRST thing the engineer should do is check the vendor's anti-spam policy and see if the emails are being quarantined from the recipient. 

I also notice some of the links in this discussion mention the anti-spam policy but the user decided to go with B?.
I would disagree with B because users cannot send emails to any destination, so why would the issue be on the destination emails' gateway?

comments.content:
I'm going with D. As stated below, the 'reinstalling' part of A means it should be last in the troubleshooting process.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/troubleshoot/antispam/message-rejected-ndr

discussion.content: Very bad question to be honest. None of them looks really like right. Could be DNS or Security Settings of the VM/Firewall.
SPF is a record, not a Security Certificate.
I also think it should be B, A seems like a last step
The answer is: A

comments.content: i meant to B is the correct Answer!

discussion.content:
I believe the answer is B.
the question is asking what would you do FIRST. Reinstall is usually the last thing to try after troubleshooting for a bit

I don't like the wording on this question but I think A as excessive as it seems is the right answer. This link is included below so you may need to verify/confirm or reinstall software to ensure you configure the send connector correctly in something like MS Exchange Server you deploy on cloud IaaS.

https://practical365.com/exchange-server/exchange-2016-outbound-mail-flow/
Look up SPF
B http://blog.clickdimensions.com/emails-arent-received/ and A is 2 actions, so first and second? but reinstalling is a big chore.

choices.B: Validate TLS certificates on the destination email gateway.
choices.A: Confirm the email server configuration and reinstall the email server software.
choices.D: Consult the cloud vendor's anti-spam policy.

questions.question_text: A cloud engineer deployed an email server in a public cloud. Users can access the email server, but the emails they send cannot reach their destinations. Which of the following should the cloud engineer do FIRST?

choices.C: Deploy a CASB solution and whitelist the approved SaaS applications.
choices.B: Deploy a smart card login and change passwords to each SaaS vendor every 30 days.
choices.D: Deploy SSO and enforce VPN access to the corporate domain.
choices.A: Deploy an IPSec tunnel to each SaaS provider and enable biometric login.

questions.question_text:
Recent feedback from an employee engagement survey stated that users are frustrated with multiple logins to different SaaS providers, and the cloud engineering teams is directed to address this issue and implement a solution. The security policy states that users must access the SaaS from approved IP addresses.
Which of the following is the BEST and most efficient solution to deploy?

discussion.content:
C - refer to question #108 @ Topic 1.
multiple logins to different SaaS providers --> Federal related
access the SaaS from approved IP addresses -->CASB

questions.question_text:
A service engineer is trying to determine why one of the company's SaaS solution is no longer available. The internal systems are responding and other online applications using the same SaaS solution are responding as expected.
Which of the following is the MOST common cause of the availability issue?

discussion.content: Shouldn't be D?

If other applications use it fine, then it seems like it can't be a subscription or outage issue. Kind of rule out B for same reason. Maybe not greatest reasoning but thinking C just from process of elimination.

comments.content: On second thought, this question is very poorly worded......it is saying other online applications using the SAME SaaS solution is working. If this is the same solution, then it could be that it is an integration issue. Since the same SaaS solution is working, there is no outage, and the subscription is working because the same solution is working elsewhere. Maybe they are not providing all the information to us and suspect us to know this is an integrated solution.

discussion.content: More likely to be D. There is nothing to integrate, and other SAAS solutions of the same provider are still working.
I believe the answer is A. Nothing is being integrated
